journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: A new algorithm for obtaining the operating point of photovoltaic systems

article-meta.aff: School of Engineering, University of Glasgow, UK

author-notes.corresp: Liam J Maclsaac, School of Engineering, University of Glasgow, Glasgow G12 8LT, UK. Email: l.macisaac@elec.gla.ac.uk

abstract.p: A new algorithm is presented which can be used to find the operating point of a solar panel when only the load resistance is known, using a single diode ideal solar cell model. The algorithm uses a modified version of the binary search algorithm to rapidly discover the operating point of the panel, which makes it particularly suited to use within simulation environments such as Matlab/Simulink. A review of relevant solar cell theory is provided, followed by a discussion of existing methods that may be used to solve this problem. This is then followed by a full description of the new algorithm and a comparison of its performance with existing methods. An example is then provided of how the algorithm can be used to define a Thévenin equivalent model for a solar panel.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Solar cells have a non-linear current–voltage characteristic and; therefore, the power output from a solar cell depends on both the environmental conditions and the connected load. The majority of solar cell models are based on a current source in parallel with either one or two diodes.1 These models describe the output current of a solar panel in terms of the voltage across the panel, or the voltage across the panel in terms of the output current. Uses of these models are very well-documented and include applications such as the development of maximum power point tracking2–6 and photovoltaic-battery systems.7

In certain situations, it may be more desirable to describe the behaviour of a solar panel in terms of the load connected to it. The solution to this problem is not trivial as it has two unknown parameters (voltage and current), which introduces the need for numerical techniques to solve for the operating point.

‘Solar panel models’ of this article reviews the methods that are presently used to model solar cells and describes how one of these methods may be used to model a solar panel. The next section describes panel ‘operating point detection’ and presents two existing methods which can be used for this purpose followed by the new operating point ‘detection algorithm’. Finally, comparisons between the new algorithm and existing methods are carried out and an example is provided of how operating point detection can assist in the definition of a Thévenin equivalent model for a solar panel.

sec.title: Two-diode model
sec.p:
The two-diode solar cell model and its variants have been widely used in the literature for studies on photovoltaic systems.8–11 The two-diode solar cell model is illustrated in Figure 1 and can be described in terms of incident irradiation, cell temperature and voltage, as in equation (1) (1) Figure 1.
Two-diode solar cell model.

S is the incident level of solar irradiation in W/m2, T the cell temperature in Kelvin, V the voltage across the cell in Volts and m1 and m2 the dimensionless ideality factors of the diodes in the model. VT (T) is the thermal voltage for a given temperature in Kelvin, given by VT (T) = kT/q where k is the Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10−23 J/K), q the electron charge (1.6 × 10−19 C) and RS and RP the series and shunt resistances in Ohms. It can be observed that I appears on both sides of equation (1) and; therefore, numerical techniques are required to solve this equation for I.

The photocurrent, IPH, generated by the photovoltaic conversion process, can be expressed in terms of the solar irradiation, S, a reference level of solar irradiation, SR and the photocurrent in Amps at the reference level IPHR, as shown in equation (2) (2)IPH(S)=IPHRSSR

The reverse saturation currents of the diodes in the model IRS1 and IRS2 represent losses in the conversion process which are dependent on temperature. In general, a reverse saturation current, IRS, can be expressed by equation (3) in terms of the cell temperature T (K), a reference temperature TR (K), the reverse saturation current at the reference temperature IRSR (A), the band gap energy of the semiconductor used to manufacture the cell ε (1.12 eV for silicon), the diode ideality factor m and VT and VTR which are the thermal voltages at T and TR, respectively, in Volts (3)IRS(T)=IRSR(TTR)3exp(ɛm(1VTR-1VT))

sec.title: Single diode model
sec.p:
The single diode solar cell model, shown in Figure 2, combines the diffusion and recombination losses represented by the two diodes in the two-diode model into a single diode which approximates the combined loss due to both currents. While this provides a less accurate way of modelling a solar cell, it offers the advantage of fewer parameters to compute when characterising a solar cell using this model and as a result the model has gained widespread acceptance in studies involving solar cells.12–14 Figure 2.
Single diode solar cell model.

The single diode solar cell model can be expressed by equation (4) where m1 and m2 from the two-diode model are replaced by a single ideality factor, m, and IRS1 and IRS2 are replaced with a single reverse saturation current IRS. It should be noted again that I appears on both sides of this equation and; therefore, numerical methods are required to solve this equation (4)I(S,T,V)=IPH(S)-IRS(T)(exp(V+RSImVT(T))-1) -V+RSIRP

To simplify the model further and eliminate the need for numerical solutions, the assumption can be made that the series resistance, RS, is significantly small that it can be set to zero and that the shunt resistance is significantly large that it can be set to ∞. This produces equation (5) which may be solved for I in terms of V without the use of numerical methods (5)I(S,T,V)=IPH(S)-IRS(T)(exp(VmVT(T))-1)

sec.title: Solar panel model
sec.p: Equations (2), (3) and (5) can also be used when considering a panel built from a parallel and series combination of solar cells; however, adjustments to the parameters need to be made to take this into account.1 In equation (2), IPHR is given by IPHR = IPHR_PANEL/NP where IPHR_PANEL is the panel’s photocurrent at reference conditions in Amps and NP the number of parallel networks of cells in the panel. Similarly in equation (3), IRSR is given by IRSR = IRSR_PANEL/NP.

To obtain the output current for the entire panel, the modified version of equation (5), given in equation (6) should be used where NS is the number of cells in each series network within the panel and NP the number of parallel networks of cells connected in series. V is the voltage across the panel. It should be noted that equation (6) assumes uniform irradiation across all cells and does not take into account any partial shading of the panel. However, it is a suitable model to demonstrate the proposed new algorithm (6)

sec.title: Operating point detection
sec.p: From equation (6), the output current of a solar panel can be determined trivially if the voltage across the panel is known. Similarly, the equation may be rearranged to determine the voltage if the current is known. However, it is non-trivial to determine the voltage and current if only the load resistance is known as both the voltage and current are unknown.

To simplify the solution of this problem, consider Figure 3 which illustrates the model from equation (6) using the parameters of a BP SX-80 solar panel (IPHR = 4.7 A, IRSR = 9.84 × 10−10 A, m = 2.13, SR = 1000 W/m2 and TR = 298.15 K), with atmospheric conditions of S = 1000 W/m2 and T = 25°C (298.15 K). Additionally, the plot shows the equivalent load resistance for each I/V point. This is the resistance that is required for the solar panel to operate at each point on the I/V curve. Figure 3.
Illustration of the I/V characteristic of a BP SX-80 solar panel showing the equivalent load required to obtain each operating voltage.

If the load resistance is known, it is possible to determine the operating point of the solar panel by obtaining the operating voltage from the R/V curve and hence the current using equation (6). This eliminates the need to solve an equation with two unknown values. This technique is a variation on the ‘load line’ technique which can be used to find the operating point of a diode as discussed in Hambley.15 However, when carrying out simulations involving photovoltaic systems, a graphical method provides little benefit and therefore, some form of computational technique for performing the operating point detection must be used. The remainder of this section describes existing computational methods which can be used to detect the operating point of a solar cell.

sec.title: Linear search
sec.p: The most basic form of evaluation of the operating point is to find the desired point on the R/V curve for the solar panel and hence, compute the current for the given voltage. Search algorithms allow for the R/V curve to be searched for a given load resistance and the voltage to be extracted from the curve. The linear search algorithm16 is one of the simplest forms of search algorithm.

To determine the operating point using the linear search algorithm, the current should be computed using equation (6), initially setting V = 0. The resistance can then be calculated by dividing the voltage by the calculated current. If the resistance is less than the desired load value, the voltage should be incremented by a small value and the process repeated until the algorithm either finds the desired resistance, or finds a value larger than the desired load. The accuracy of this algorithm is directly dependent on the value that the voltage is incremented by – smaller values will produce more accurate results but cause the algorithm to take longer to reach the solution.

sec.title: Newton’s method
sec.p: An alternative to searching for the operating point using the panel’s R/V curve is to use Ohm’s law in conjunction with equation (6) to express resistance in terms of voltage, as in equation (7). To determine the operating point of the solar panel, equation (7) can be solved for V for a given value of R. The voltage obtained may then be used with equation (6) to determine the current (7)R=VNp(IPH(S)-IRS(T)(exp(VNSmVT(T))-1))

Although there is no analytical solution to equation (7), Newton’s method17 may be used to solve for the voltage. Newton’s method, defined in equation (8) is a successive approximation solver which begins with an initial estimate at the solution, xn and uses this to determine a more accurate approximation to the solution, xn + 1. This process is continued with each approximate solution until xn + 1 is within a given tolerance of xn (8)xn+1=xn-f(xn)f'(xn)

In order to solve equation (7) using Newton’s method, it must be rearranged into the form given in equation (9) and additionally the derivative given in equation (10) is required (9)f(v)=VNp(IPH(S)-IRS(T)(exp(VNSmVT(T))-1))-R (10)f'(v)=1Np(IPH(S)-IRS(T)(exp(VmNSVT(T))-1)) +IRS(T)·V·exp(VmNSVT(T))NS·NP·m·VT(T)· (IPH(S)-IRS(T)·(exp(VmNSVT(T))-1))

sec.title: New detection algorithm
sec.p: The new operating point detection algorithm that was developed is a search-based algorithm which utilises a variant of the well-known binary search technique18 to search the R/V curve of a solar panel for a known load resistance to find its operating point.

The algorithm, illustrated in Figure 4, begins by setting a voltage variable to zero. Equation (6) is then used to calculate the current and hence the resistance for that voltage. If the resistance is less than the known load resistance, the voltage is incremented by a given step size and the algorithm begins another iteration. If the resistance is greater than the known load resistance, the voltage is set to its previous value and the step size is divided by 10. This process continues until either the load resistance is found, or the step size reaches a specified minimum value. Figure 4.
Illustration of the new algorithm developed to determine the operating point of a solar panel when the load resistance is known. The current I (V) is obtained from equation (6).

The overall effect of the algorithm is to rapidly converge to close to the known load value and then to search more precisely as the value is reached. The main property which governs the accuracy of the algorithm is the minimum step size. Smaller values will result in the algorithm taking longer to converge to a more accurate solution while larger values will result in faster convergence but a less accurate solution.

It is important to note that when using this algorithm that the error in the result is not constant throughout the full range of operation. This is due to the non-linear characteristic of solar panels. From Figure 3, it can be observed that from 0 to 15 V a linear increase in load resistance results in a linear increase in the voltage across the panel. However, from 15 V onwards, exponential increases in the load resistance result in linear increases in the voltage.

This characteristic means that because of the fixed minimum voltage step size that the algorithm uses, significantly more accurate results will be obtained in the linear part of the characteristic than those obtained in the exponential part.

sec.title: Comparison of methods
sec.p: A comparison of the new algorithm was carried out with the linear search and the Newton methods to measure its performance against that of the other algorithms. Comparisons will be performed on the range of resistance values for which the algorithms can obtain a solution, the time taken to reach a solution and the accuracy of the solutions obtained. The comparison was carried out by selecting voltage points between 0 and 25 V in increments of 0.01 V and calculating the current and resistance for each for the BP SX-80 module. The calculated resistances are used as the test inputs to each of the algorithms and the voltage and current values are used as the reference operating point for each resistance which the values calculated by the algorithms can be compared to. To provide a fair comparison between each algorithm, the tolerance for the Newton solver was set at 1 nV and the minimum step sizes for the linear search algorithm and the new algorithm were also set at 1 nV. The Newton solver was set to have an initial guess of 0 V for the operating point in each instance.

The first comparison that was carried out was of the range of resistance values for which the algorithms can obtain a solution. Figure 5 shows the results for the linear search algorithm, Figure 6 shows the results for the Newton method algorithm and Figure 7 shows the results for the newly developed algorithm. It can be seen from these results that the linear algorithm is able to solve over the entire range of resistances provided to it, the Newton method algorithm begins to fail nearer the open circuit voltage and new algorithm solves for all given values, with a slight error near the open circuit voltage. The reason for the Newton solver failing near the open circuit voltage is that equation (9) has a stationary point near the open circuit which will cause a division by zero error in the Newton method calculation when it operates in this region. Figure 5.
Illustration showing the range over which the linear search algorithm was able to obtain I/V operating points for the BP SX-80 solar panel. Figure 6.
Illustration showing the range over which the Newton’s method algorithm was able to obtain I/V operating points for the BP SX-80 solar panel. Figure 7.
Illustration showing the range over which the newly developed algorithm was able to obtain I/V operating points for the BP SX-80 solar panel.

The second comparison was the time that was taken for each algorithm to obtain a solution for the same set of test data used previously. The results of this comparison using an irradiation of 1000 W/m2 are shown in Figure 8. It can be observed from these results that Newton’s method was the fastest to reach a solution with an average time of 0.01 ms, followed by the new algorithm with an average time of 0.1 ms. The linear search was considerably slower as the time taken to obtain each solution was directly proportional to the resistance value. The average time for the linear search algorithm to find a solution was 2.14 s. Figure 8.
Comparison of the time taken to reach a solution for each algorithm using an irradiation level of 1000 W/m2. The values for 500 W/m2 are excluded from this illustration because they are of similar magnitude.

The final comparison performed between the three algorithms was one of the accuracy of each algorithm. In this case, the error between the operating voltage obtained by each algorithm and the actual operating voltage of the panel was used for the comparison. The comparison was carried out using irradiation levels of 500 and 1000 W/m2. The results are presented in Table 1. It can be observed from this table that the Newton’s method provides the most accurate results, followed by the linear search algorithm with the new algorithm performing most poorly. It should be noted, however that the large error contribution in the new algorithm is in the voltage range within 1 V of the open circuit voltage, which is well beyond the range that the Newton method solver is capable of obtaining solutions in. If this range is disregarded then the maximum error is reduced to around 1 × 10−9 V in both cases. Table 1.
Comparison of result errors in operating point detection algorithms.
Algorithm 500 W/m2 Comparison 1000 W/m2 Comparison
Minimum error (V) Average error (V) Maximum error (V) Minimum error (V) Average error (V) Maximum error (V)
Linear search 0 6.56 × 10−7 1 × 10−6 0 6.35 × 10−7 1 × 10−6
Newton’s method 0 9.61 × 10−17 1.06 × 10−14 0 3.91 × 10−17 1.06 × 10−14
New algorithm 0 0.012 1 0 0.022 1

sec.title: Definition of the Thévenin equivalent model
sec.p: One possible application of operating point detection algorithms for solar panels is to assist with the definition of a Thévenin equivalent model for a solar panel. An advantage of using such a model is that it provides an accurate representation of the steady-state behaviour of the panel at that particular set of operating conditions, removing the need for more complex calculations involved with the full solar panel model. This is particularly desirable in large simulations involving solar panels.

A method previously presented in the literature8 to establish a Thévenin equivalent circuit for a solar panel is to define a linear model which crosses the axes at the open circuit voltage VOC and the short circuit current ISC, as shown in equation (11) (11)I(V)=ISC-ISCVOCV

The model in equation (11) is a linear model which exactly matches the open circuit and short circuit characteristics of the non-linear solar panel model but introduces an error throughout the whole region of operation between these points. The Thévenin equivalent model which will be proposed in this article involves finding a tangent to the solar panel’s I/V curve at the known operating point. The result of this process is the definition of a Thévenin equivalent which is inaccurate to the VOC and ISC conditions of the panel but has no error at the known operating point and a small error around the known operating point.

For a solar panel, the tangent to the I/V curve at a particular operating voltage VOP is defined by equation (12) where I(S, T, V) is given in equation (6) and I′(S, T, V) is the derivative of equation (6) with respect to V, given by equation (13). Equation (12) can be used to determine a Thévenin equivalent model of the solar panel by first setting V = 0 to obtain the Norton current IN and then setting I = 0 to obtain the Thévenin voltage VTH. The Thévenin equivalent resistance RTH can then be computed by dividing the Thévenin voltage by the Norton current. These values can then be used in the Thévenin equivalent circuit, shown in Figure 9 (12) (13)I'(S,T,V)=-NPIRS(T)exp(VmNSVT(T))mNSVT(T) Figure 9.
Thévenin equivalent circuit.

sec.title: Thévenin equivalent model example
sec.p:
To provide an illustrative example of the use of the operating point detection algorithm, the case will be considered where a BP SX-80 solar panel is connected to a load network with an equivalent resistance of 5 Ω. Using the new operating point detection algorithm, the operating voltage was determined for the fixed load of 5 Ω under varying solar irradiation levels. In each case, the equation for the tangent to the panel’s I/V curve at the detected operating point was determined using equation (12). The Thévenin model parameters were then extracted from this equation. The results are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Using the operating point detection algorithm to determine Thévenin equivalent models for a BP SX-80 solar panel for varying irradiation levels.
Irradiation level (W/m2) Voltage for 5 Ω load (V) Current for 5 Ω load (A) Equation of tangent Thévenin voltage (V) Thévenin resistance (Ω)
250 5.8750 1.1750 1.175–3.864 × 10−7 V 3.0409 × 106 2.588 × 106
500 11.7493 2.3499 2.3516–0.0001495 V 15,729.8 6688.96
750 17.3982 3.4796 4.2803–0.046 V 93.0489 21.7391
1000 20.0747 4.0149 17.9641–0.6949 V 25.8513 1.4391

Figure 10 shows the I/V characteristic of the Thévenin equivalent models of the solar panel compared to the non-linear characteristic of the single diode models. It can be observed from the graph that the Thévenin equivalent models exactly match the single diode models at the selected operating point and provide a good approximation around this point. This indicates that it may be possible to use the Thévenin equivalent model in place of the full model if only a small range of operation of the panel is to be considered. Figure 10.
Illustration showing the single diode solar panel model for a BP SX-80 panel for varying irradiation levels (solid lines) and the Thévenin equivalent models (dotted lines) for each irradiation level when a 5 Ω load is connected to the panel.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new algorithm has been presented which is capable of rapidly finding the I/V operating point of a solar panel when only the load resistance is known. In the test cases presented in this article, the algorithm was capable of reaching a solution within 0.1 ms on average, making it suitable for online use within simulations. The algorithm uses a modification of the binary search algorithm which allows it to converge to a solution more rapidly than through the use of a linear search. In the test cases provided, linear search was 20,000 times slower than the new algorithm on average. The algorithm also out-performed the Newton’s method numerical solver when operating close to the open circuit voltage where a stationary point prevented the Newton solver from reaching a solution. The Newton solver was, however, faster over the range where it was able to obtain a solution, obtaining a solution within 0.01 ms on average.

Despite being the slowest of the algorithms, the linear search algorithm is the most accurate of the three over the entire range of operation of the panel, obtaining solutions over the whole range with a maximum error of 0.656 μV. The Newton’s method solver was the most accurate over the range in which it was capable of operating with a maximum error of 0.001 pV but it failed to obtain results near the open circuit voltage. The new algorithm was able to obtain results over the whole range of operation the panel but these were inaccurate within 1 V of the open circuit voltage, giving a maximum error of 1 V. Outwith this range, the maximum error of the algorithm was 1 nV, out-performing the linear search.

One particular application of the new algorithm – the definition of a Thévenin equivalent model for a photovoltaic system – was presented. This model can be particularly useful for simplifying the single diode model of a photovoltaic system into a linear approximation, provided that the loading of the panel remains within a small range. It may also be beneficial in simulations where a number of different loading conditions are being considered to evaluate the Thévenin equivalent model for each condition as the linear equivalent model can save processing time compared to the non-linear single diode model.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by a Doctoral Training Award from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (grant number EP/P50418X/1) and the Glasgow Research Partnership in Engineering.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.
